title: Pan-Roasted Sea Trout, Pickled Cucumber, Dill & Lemon Whey — Foodie Fuel
method: Heat oven to 200°C (fan 180°C). Bring a small pan of salted water to the boil for the broccoli.
Make quick pickle: shave cucumber into ribbons. Warm vinegar, sugar and a pinch of salt until dissolved, then pour over cucumber. Chill 10 minutes.
Make lemon whey: whisk buttermilk with lemon zest and 1 tsp lemon juice, then strain through a clean cloth or fine sieve for 5 minutes. Stir in chopped dill.
Season trout. Heat a non‑stick pan on medium‑high, add rapeseed oil, place trout skin-side down and press for 20 seconds. Cook 4 minutes until skin crisp.
Flip trout, add capers to the pan, then transfer pan to oven for 4–5 minutes until just opaque.
Blanch broccoli 2 minutes, drain, and toss with a squeeze of lemon and a pinch of salt.
plating: Spoon lemon whey in a crescent on warm plates.
Set trout on the whey with capers scattered over the fish.
Twist pickled cucumber ribbons beside the trout, add broccoli, and finish with a dusting of toasted oat bran and dill fronds.
optional_finishes: A few drops of extra virgin olive oil
swaps: Salmon works well if sea trout is unavailable.
hydrationTip: Pair with sparkling water and a wedge of lemon to lift the citrus notes.

diabetesUK.basis: Heuristic screen for higher fibre, no added sugars, and moderated carbs; portion guidance still applies.

notes: Uses olive, coconut, or avocado oil only. No seed oils.

title: Hebridean Scallops, Cauliflower Purée, Pea Shoots & Caper Brown Butter — Foodie Fuel
method: Heat oven to 210°C (fan 190°C).
Simmer cauliflower with garlic in milk and 100 ml water for 10–12 minutes until tender; blend smooth, season.
Cook peas in boiling water for 2 minutes, drain and lightly crush with lemon zest and a pinch of salt.
Pat scallops dry and season. Heat a pan on high, add rapeseed oil, sear scallops 60–75 seconds per side until caramelised.
Add butter and capers, cook 30 seconds until nutty and foaming; finish with 1 tsp lemon juice.
plating: Spoon cauliflower purée into the centre of warm plates.
Arrange scallops on top; spoon brown butter and capers over.
Add crushed peas and pea shoots to one side; finish with lemon zest.
optional_finishes: A pinch of flaky sea salt
swaps: Use langoustines instead of scallops for a richer celebration option.
hydrationTip: Still water with lemon keeps the palate clean between bites.

diabetesUK.basis: Heuristic screen for higher fibre, no added sugars, and moderated carbs; portion guidance still applies.

notes: Uses olive, coconut, or avocado oil only. No seed oils.

title: Venison Loin, Roasted Celeriac, Blackcurrant & Juniper — Foodie Fuel
method: Heat oven to 200°C (fan 180°C). Peel celeriac, cut into 2 cm cubes. Toss with oil, juniper and salt; roast 30–35 minutes, turning once.
Warm stock with blackcurrant jam, vinegar and mustard; simmer 6–8 minutes to a glossy sauce.
Blanch kale 2 minutes, drain well, and season with a pinch of salt and a teaspoon of sauce.
Season venison. Sear in a hot pan with oil for 2 minutes per side. Add butter, baste 30 seconds.
Rest venison 5 minutes, then slice.
plating: Pile roasted celeriac neatly as a base.
Fan sliced venison across the celeriac and spoon sauce around, not over, the meat.
Add kale as a tight side mound and finish with cracked black pepper.
swaps: Lean beef fillet can substitute venison if needed.
hydrationTip: Sparkling water with a dash of blackcurrant cordial (light) echoes the sauce.

diabetesUK.basis: Heuristic screen for higher fibre, no added sugars, and moderated carbs; portion guidance still applies.

notes: Uses olive, coconut, or avocado oil only. No seed oils.

title: Slow-Braised Beef Cheek, Pearl Barley & Burnt Onion Jus — Foodie Fuel
method: Heat oven to 150°C (fan 130°C).
Season cheeks. Brown in a casserole with oil, 3–4 minutes per side; remove.
Char the cut side of onion in the pot until very dark. Add carrots, celery, garlic; cook 6 minutes.
Stir in tomato purée, then add stock and wine. Return cheeks, cover and braise 2½ hours until spoon-tender.
Rinse barley. Simmer with water and a pinch of salt for 25–30 minutes until tender; fold through mushrooms and thyme for the last 5 minutes.
Reduce braising liquid on the hob for 8–10 minutes to a glossy jus; strain if you want a fine finish.
plating: Spoon barley and mushrooms into the centre.
Set a cheek on top and nap with a small amount of jus.
Finish with thyme and a few flakes of sea salt.
optional_finishes: A squeeze of lemon to brighten the jus
hydrationTip: Still water with lemon helps cut the richness.

diabetesUK.basis: Heuristic screen for higher fibre, no added sugars, and moderated carbs; portion guidance still applies.

notes: Uses olive, coconut, or avocado oil only. No seed oils.

title: Roast Monkfish, Smoked Mussel Broth, Leeks & Parsley Oil — Foodie Fuel
method: Heat oven to 200°C (fan 180°C). Season monkfish; rub with rapeseed oil.
Roast monkfish on a tray for 18–22 minutes until just firm; rest 5 minutes.
Meanwhile, sweat leek, fennel and garlic in a pan with 1 tsp oil for 8 minutes.
Add mussels and wine, cover and steam 4–5 minutes until opened. Discard any that stay closed.
Add fish stock and simmer 6 minutes. Blend parsley with olive oil and 1 tbsp broth to make a green oil.
Simmer cavolo nero in the broth for 3 minutes until tender.
plating: Slice monkfish into medallions.
Pour smoked mussel broth into a warm bowl, add leeks, fennel and cavolo nero.
Place monkfish on top and finish with parsley oil in small droplets.
swaps: Use hake or cod loin if monkfish is unavailable (reduce roast time).
hydrationTip: Sparkling water helps lift the briny broth.

diabetesUK.basis: Heuristic screen for higher fibre, no added sugars, and moderated carbs; portion guidance still applies.

notes: Uses olive, coconut, or avocado oil only. No seed oils.

title: Lamb Rump, Charred Brassicas, Anchovy-Mustard Dressing — Foodie Fuel
method: Heat oven to 210°C (fan 190°C).
Season lamb. Sear in a hot ovenproof pan with rapeseed oil, fat-side down 3 minutes, then 2 minutes the other side.
Transfer to oven and roast 10–12 minutes for pink (58–60°C internal), or 14 minutes for medium. Rest 8 minutes.
Blanch broccoli 2 minutes. Toss sprouts and broccoli with a pinch of salt and char in the same pan over high heat 4–5 minutes.
Blend anchovy, mustard, olive oil, lemon juice and garlic into a dressing.
plating: Slice lamb and fan over charred brassicas.
Drizzle anchovy-mustard dressing in a thin line, keeping the plate clean.
Finish with cracked black pepper and a squeeze of lemon.
hydrationTip: Still water with lemon balances the salty dressing.

diabetesUK.basis: Heuristic screen for higher fibre, no added sugars, and moderated carbs; portion guidance still applies.

notes: Uses olive, coconut, or avocado oil only. No seed oils.

title: Roast Chicken, Light Bread Sauce, Kale & Apple — Foodie Fuel

ingredients.item: Chicken breasts with skin (or 2 small supremes)

method: Heat oven to 190°C (fan 170°C). Season chicken; rub with oil.
Roast chicken on a tray for 22–26 minutes until 74°C internal; rest 6 minutes.
For light bread sauce: simmer onion, bay and peppercorns in milk 10 minutes; strain. Whisk in breadcrumbs and simmer 2–3 minutes to thicken.
Cook kale in boiling water 2 minutes, drain well.
Warm apple slices in a pan with vinegar and a pinch of salt for 2 minutes.
plating: Spoon bread sauce into a shallow pool.
Slice chicken and lay over the sauce to keep the skin crisp.
Add kale and apple to the side; finish with cracked black pepper.
optional_finishes: A pinch of nutmeg in the bread sauce
swaps: Use turkey breast if preferred (same roasting time if similar thickness).
hydrationTip: Still water or a light apple spritz pairs well with the apple note.

diabetesUK.basis: Heuristic screen for higher fibre, no added sugars, and moderated carbs; portion guidance still applies.

notes: Uses olive, coconut, or avocado oil only. No seed oils.

title: Smoked Haddock & Leek Chowder (Lightened) with Oat Crunch — Foodie Fuel
method: Sweat leek and celery in a lidded pan with 2 tbsp water for 6–8 minutes until soft.
Add potato and fish stock; simmer 12–15 minutes until potato is tender.
Add haddock and milk; poach gently for 6–8 minutes until flakes.
Remove fish, flake into chunks. Blend half the soup briefly for body (optional), return fish.
Stir in oat bran and simmer 2 minutes. Finish with chives and lemon juice.
plating: Ladle into bowls and top with toasted oats for crunch.
Finish with chives and a squeeze of lemon.
swaps: Use smoked mackerel for a stronger flavour (reduce poach to 4–5 minutes).
hydrationTip: Sparkling water with lemon keeps it fresh.

diabetesUK.basis: Heuristic screen for higher fibre, no added sugars, and moderated carbs; portion guidance still applies.

notes: Uses olive, coconut, or avocado oil only. No seed oils.

title: Mushroom & Barley ‘Risotto’, Roast Garlic & Watercress — Foodie Fuel
method: Heat oven to 200°C (fan 180°C). Wrap whole garlic cloves in foil and roast 20 minutes until soft.
Sauté onion in olive oil 6 minutes. Add mushrooms and cook 8 minutes until browned.
Stir in barley. Add stock in ladles, simmering and stirring for 30–35 minutes until barley is tender and glossy.
Stir in parmesan and squeeze in roasted garlic. Finish with lemon juice and season.
Toss watercress with a pinch of salt and a few drops of olive oil.
plating: Spoon barley ‘risotto’ into bowls and tap to level.
Top with watercress and a light dusting of parmesan.
swaps: Use pecorino instead of parmesan for a sharper finish.
hydrationTip: Still water with lemon complements the earthy mushrooms.

diabetesUK.basis: Heuristic screen for higher fibre, no added sugars, and moderated carbs; portion guidance still applies.

notes: Uses olive, coconut, or avocado oil only. No seed oils.

title: Roast Beetroot, Crowdie-Style Whipped Cottage Cheese & Walnut-Oat Crumb — Foodie Fuel
method: Heat oven to 200°C (fan 180°C). Wrap beetroot in foil and roast 45–55 minutes until a knife slides in easily.
Cool slightly, peel, then cut into wedges. Toss with vinegar, oil and a pinch of salt.
Whip cottage cheese with yoghurt and honey until smooth; season lightly.
Mix walnuts and oats; toast in a dry pan 2 minutes until fragrant.
plating: Spoon whipped cheese into a broad smear.
Arrange beetroot wedges with cut sides visible.
Scatter walnut-oat crumb and add rocket lightly dressed.
swaps: Use skyr instead of yoghurt for a tangier finish.
hydrationTip: Still water with a squeeze of lemon keeps this bright.

diabetesUK.basis: Heuristic screen for higher fibre, no added sugars, and moderated carbs; portion guidance still applies.

notes: Uses olive, coconut, or avocado oil only. No seed oils.

title: Charred Cabbage Steaks, Lentil-Walnut Ragù & Mustard Herb Oil — Foodie Fuel
method: Heat oven to 210°C (fan 190°C). Slice cabbage into 2 thick steaks, keeping the core intact.
Brush steaks with rapeseed oil, season, and roast 25 minutes. Finish under the grill 2–3 minutes for charred edges.
Make ragù: sauté onion and garlic 6 minutes. Stir in tomato purée, lentils, walnuts and stock; simmer 12 minutes until thick.
Blend herbs with olive oil, mustard and vinegar to make a sharp herb oil.
plating: Place a cabbage steak on each plate.
Spoon lentil-walnut ragù over the centre only, leaving the charred edges visible.
Drizzle mustard herb oil around the plate and finish with herbs.
swaps: Use puy lentils for a firmer texture if preferred.
hydrationTip: Still water with a splash of apple juice pairs well with the mustard note.

diabetesUK.basis: Heuristic screen for higher fibre, no added sugars, and moderated carbs; portion guidance still applies.

notes: Uses olive, coconut, or avocado oil only. No seed oils.

title: Stuffed Delicata Squash, Herby Pearl Couscous & Pomegranate — Foodie Fuel
method: Heat oven to 200°C (fan 180°C). Halve squash lengthways and scoop seeds. Brush with oil and roast cut-side down 25 minutes.
Simmer pearl couscous in stock 10–12 minutes until tender; stir through pepper, chickpeas, cumin and paprika for the last 3 minutes.
Flip squash and roast 8 minutes more to caramelise edges.
Stir mint and lemon juice through couscous; season.
Fill squash cavities with the couscous mix, top with feta and return to oven 5 minutes to warm through.
plating: Serve each stuffed half on a warm plate.
Scatter pomegranate seeds and extra mint.
Keep the plate clean and finish with a small lemon wedge.
swaps: For vegan: replace feta with a spoon of hummus and extra herbs.
hydrationTip: Still water with mint and lemon matches the finish.

diabetesUK.basis: Heuristic screen for higher fibre, no added sugars, and moderated carbs; portion guidance still applies.

notes: Uses olive, coconut, or avocado oil only. No seed oils.
